Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: An optional, drop-in adult education class on a general topic is scheduled.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing the text from my boyfriend: “Can’t wait for tonight. Just us.” It’s the only evening we have together before I leave for a week of conferences and he starts his own whirlwind of work. I promised him this night—no distractions, just the two of us, maybe dinner and a walk by the river. But as I set the table, my email pings. A reminder: the adult education class at the synagogue is tonight. It’s optional, but I know a few regulars count on me to be there, to answer questions, to guide them through the week’s Torah portion. I picture the expectant faces, the quiet hunger for connection and learning. My heart tugs in two directions—toward the man I love, who needs my presence, and toward my community, who look to me for wisdom and comfort. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, the impossibility of being fully present for both. I stand in the kitchen, torn, the evening stretching before me, waiting for a choice I’m not ready to make.
